standard.name: ISO 22301
standard.description: ISO 22301 is an international standard for Business Continuity Management (BCM). It specifies requirements to plan, establish, implement, operate, monitor, review, maintain, and continually improve a documented management system to protect against, reduce the likelihood of, and ensure your business recovers from disruptive incidents.

requirements.name: Business Impact Analysis (BIA)
requirements.description: The organization shall conduct a Business Impact Analysis to identify, quantify, and qualify impacts of loss, interruption, or disruption of activities.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment
requirements.description: Perform a risk assessment to identify threats to business operations and the likelihood and impact of these threats.

standard.name: NIST SP 800-34
standard.description: The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) Special Publication 800-34 provides a framework for federal agencies and other organizations to establish and implement plans for recovering critical IT systems and operations after a disaster.

requirements.name: IT Contingency Planning
requirements.description: Develop and maintain IT contingency plans to ensure continuity of operations for IT systems.

requirements.name: Training and Awareness Programs
requirements.description: Establish training and awareness programs for disaster recovery teams and other relevant personnel.

controls.name: Regular DR Drills
controls.description: Conduct regular disaster recovery drills to test the effectiveness of the recovery plan and team readiness.

controls.name: Off-Site Data Backup
controls.description: Implement regular off-site data backup to ensure data availability in case of a disaster.

controls.name: Emergency Communication System
controls.description: Establish an emergency communication system to ensure consistent and reliable communication during disaster recovery operations.

risks.name: Unprepared Recovery Team
risks.description: If the recovery team is unprepared, it may lead to delays and inefficiency during disaster recovery operations.

risks.name: Data Loss
risks.description: Failure to back up data regularly can lead to significant data loss during a disaster.

risks.name: Communication Breakdown
risks.description: Inconsistent or failed communication during a disaster can lead to uncoordinated recovery efforts.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 20000
standard.description: The ISO/IEC 20000 standard is an international standard for IT service management. It specifies requirements for the service provider to plan, establish, implement, operate, monitor, review, maintain, and improve a Service Management System (SMS). The standard is applicable to any organization or part of an organization, irrespective of the size, type, and nature of the services delivered.

requirements.name: Define and Implement Change Management Process
requirements.description: Establish a documented process for managing changes. It should include criteria for accepting and categorizing change requests, assessment of changes, authorization, and implementation of changes. It's crucial for maintaining service quality and avoiding unnecessary disruptions.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment for Changes
requirements.description: Ensure changes are assessed for risks. This includes analyzing potential impacts on existing services and mitigating risks before implementation. It's essential to minimize service outages and maintain service continuity.

standard.name: ITIL (Information Technology Infrastructure Library)
standard.description: ITIL is a set of detailed practices for IT service management (ITSM) that focuses on aligning IT services with the needs of business. It describes processes, procedures, tasks, and checklists that can be applied by an organization for establishing integration with the organization’s strategy, delivering value, and maintaining a minimum level of competency.

requirements.name: Release and Deployment Management
requirements.description: Define and implement a formal release and deployment management process. This includes planning, scheduling, and controlling the movement of releases to test and live environments. It ensures that integrity is maintained.

requirements.name: Post-Implementation Review
requirements.description: Conduct a review after the implementation of changes to capture lessons learned and ensure that the change has achieved its intended purpose. It helps in continuous improvement and identifying any gaps.

controls.name: Change Approval Board (CAB) Review
controls.description: Establish a Change Approval Board (CAB) responsible for the evaluation and approval of change requests. The CAB should include representatives from various business units to ensure a comprehensive impact assessment. This control is crucial for preventing unauthorized or high-risk changes from being implemented. It is recommended to occur weekly or as needed based on the volume of changes.

controls.name: Automated Risk Assessment Tools
controls.description: Implement automated tools to assess the risk of proposed changes. These tools should provide a quantitative risk score and highlight areas of potential impact. The use of automation can enhance accuracy and provide timely evaluations. This assessment should be done for every change request before CAB review.

controls.name: Scheduled Release Windows
controls.description: Define and enforce scheduled release windows for deploying changes. These windows should be communicated to all stakeholders and planned during off-peak hours to minimize disruption. This control is essential for managing conflicts and ensuring a systematic deployment process. Scheduling should be done monthly or as per the agreed maintenance calendar.

risks.name: Unauthorized Changes
risks.description: Changes implemented without proper authorization can lead to service disruptions, security vulnerabilities, and non-compliance with regulatory requirements. This risk is mitigated by the Change Approval Board (CAB) Review (CTRL-0001). If not addressed, it can result in significant operational and financial impacts.

risks.name: Service Downtime Due to Unassessed Risks
risks.description: Unassessed risks in change requests can cause unexpected service downtimes, impacting business continuity and customer satisfaction. Automated Risk Assessment Tools (CTRL-0002) can help identify and mitigate these risks before implementation. Failure to address this risk can lead to loss of revenue and tarnished reputation.

risks.name: Deployment Conflicts
risks.description: Without scheduled release windows, there can be conflicts in deployment schedules leading to service outages and operational inefficiencies. The Scheduled Release Windows control (CTRL-0003) helps prevent such conflicts. Ignoring this risk can disrupt business operations and lead to unsatisfied stakeholders.

standard.name: ITIL (Information Technology Infrastructure Library)
standard.description: ITIL is a set of detailed practices for IT service management (ITSM) that focuses on aligning IT services with the needs of business. It provides a framework for managing IT services, emphasizing continuous improvement and best practices for incident and problem management.

requirements.name: Incident Logging and Categorization
requirements.description: All incidents must be logged and categorized accurately to ensure efficient tracking and resolution. This helps in prioritizing incidents and allocating appropriate resources.

requirements.name: Root Cause Analysis
requirements.description: A structured approach to identifying the root causes of problems to prevent future incidents. This is critical for improving the stability and reliability of IT services.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 20000
standard.description: ISO/IEC 20000 is an international standard for IT service management. It specifies requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving a service management system (SMS).

requirements.name: Service Continuity and Availability Management
requirements.description: Ensures that IT services are resilient and can recover quickly from incidents, maintaining business continuity.

requirements.name: Problem Management Procedures
requirements.description: Defines standardized procedures for problem management, ensuring timely identification, management, and resolution of problems.

controls.name: Incident Monitoring and Reporting
controls.description: Implement continuous monitoring and regular reporting of incidents to ensure quick detection and response.

controls.name: Regular Root Cause Analysis Reviews
controls.description: Conduct regular reviews of root cause analyses to identify patterns and implement preventative measures. This should be done monthly.

controls.name: Implementation of Problem Management Policies
controls.description: Develop and enforce policies for managing problems, including roles and responsibilities, escalation procedures, and communication protocols.

risks.name: Unresolved Incidents
risks.description: Failing to resolve incidents can lead to prolonged downtime, affecting business operations and customer satisfaction.

risks.name: Recurring Problems
risks.description: Without regular root cause analysis, the same issues may recur, leading to increased operational costs and reduced service reliability.

risks.name: Lack of Standardized Problem Management
risks.description: Without standardized procedures, problem management can be inconsistent and inefficient, leading to longer resolution times and potential disruptions.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 20000
standard.description: ISO/IEC 20000 is an international standard for IT service management. It specifies requirements for the service provider to plan, establish, implement, operate, monitor, review, maintain and improve an SMS. The requirements include the design, transition, delivery and improvement of services to fulfill agreed service requirements.

requirements.name: Service Level Management
requirements.description: Ensure a consistent level of performance in the delivery of services as per agreed-upon service levels. This involves monitoring and reporting metrics to verify that service levels are being met and making adjustments as necessary to continue meeting these service levels.

requirements.name: Capacity Management
requirements.description: Ensure that the capacity of IT services and the IT infrastructure is able to deliver the agreed service level targets in a cost-effective and timely manner. It necessitates monitoring IT resource usage and performance, and planning for future requirements to avoid capacity shortfalls.

requirements.name: Availability Management
requirements.description: Ensure that IT services meet the current and future availability needs of the business in a cost-effective and timely manner, ensuring the level of service availability required is provided in all circumstances.

standard.name: ITIL (Information Technology Infrastructure Library)
standard.description: ITIL is a widely adopted framework for IT service management. It provides best practices for aligning IT services with the needs of the business. ITIL helps organizations across industries offer their services in a quality-driven and economical way.

requirements.name: Performance Monitoring
requirements.description: Implement continuous monitoring to track performance metrics and ensure they meet the business needs. This involves setting performance benchmarks and comparing actual performance against these targets to identify areas for improvement.

requirements.name: Resource Optimization
requirements.description: Ensure optimal use of IT resources to improve efficiency and reduce costs. This requires continuous assessment of resource usage and reallocation as needed to address bottlenecks and imbalances.

requirements.name: Risk Management
requirements.description: Develop and maintain a risk management plan that includes identifying, analyzing, and responding to risks. This plan should also include a strategy for risk mitigation and monitoring ongoing risk factors.

standard.name: COBIT (Control Objectives for Information and Related Technologies)
standard.description: COBIT is a framework created by ISACA for IT management and governance. It provides managers, auditors, and IT users with a set of generally accepted measures, indicators, processes, and best practices to assist them in maximizing the benefits derived from the use of information technology.

requirements.name: Performance Measurement
requirements.description: Define and measure performance metrics that align IT objectives with business goals. Ensure consistent measurement and reporting to track performance trends and identify improvement opportunities.

requirements.name: Governance and Accountability
requirements.description: Ensure governance structures are in place to provide clear accountability and roles for performance management. This includes setting up committees or roles to oversee performance and capacity management efforts.

requirements.name: Service Continuity
requirements.description: Ensure IT services can continue and recover quickly following a disruption, using planning, testing, and monitoring to manage risks associated with service continuity.

controls.name: Regular Performance Reviews
controls.description: Conduct regular performance reviews to assess the performance of IT services against predefined metrics. This helps in identifying areas of improvement and ensuring that service levels are met as per SLAs.

controls.name: Automated Capacity Monitoring Tools
controls.description: Utilize automated tools to continuously monitor the capacity and performance of IT infrastructure. These tools help in the early detection of potential issues and facilitate proactive capacity management.

controls.name: Risk Assessment and Mitigation Plans
controls.description: Develop and update risk assessment and mitigation plans regularly. This involves identifying potential risks, analyzing their impact, and implementing measures to mitigate them.

risks.name: Service Downtime
risks.description: Service downtime can severely impact business operations, leading to financial losses and damaging the organization's reputation. Regular performance reviews help in identifying and rectifying performance issues before they lead to downtime.

risks.name: Capacity Shortfall
risks.description: A capacity shortfall can lead to unmet service levels, causing delays and inefficiencies. Automated capacity monitoring tools enable early detection and resolution of capacity issues, ensuring adequate IT resources are available.

risks.name: Unmitigated Risks
risks.description: Failure to address identified risks can result in unforeseen disruptions and security breaches. Regular updates to risk assessment and mitigation plans ensure that risks are managed proactively.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 27001
standard.description: ISO/IEC 27001 is an information security standard that provides a systematic approach to managing sensitive company information so that it remains secure. It includes requirements for implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an information security management system (ISMS).

requirements.name: Access Control
requirements.description: Establish policies to limit access to information and information processing facilities. Ensure only authorized individuals have access based on the principle of least privilege. This is important to prevent unauthorized access to the network infrastructure.

requirements.name: Security Policies
requirements.description: Develop, implement, and maintain information security policies that address the requirements of the ISMS. Clear policies help in defining responsibilities and expected behavior regarding network security.

standard.name: NIST SP 800-53
standard.description: NIST Special Publication 800-53 provides a catalog of security and privacy controls for federal information systems and organizations. It aims to protect organizational operations, assets, and individuals from various threats.

requirements.name: Continuous Monitoring
requirements.description: Implement an information security continuous monitoring (ISCM) capability to provide ongoing monitoring of the security state of the network infrastructure. Continuous monitoring is crucial for detecting and responding to security incidents promptly.

requirements.name: Incident Response
requirements.description: Establish an incident response capability that includes preparation, detection, analysis, and post-incident activities. This helps in managing and mitigating adverse events related to network security.

controls.name: Periodic Access Reviews
controls.description: Conduct periodic reviews of user access levels to ensure they are appropriate based on current roles and responsibilities. This helps mitigate the risk of unauthorized access.

controls.name: Security Awareness Training
controls.description: Provide regular training sessions for employees about network security policies and potential threats. This helps in ensuring that employees are aware of security risks and best practices.

controls.name: Intrusion Detection Systems
controls.description: Deploy and maintain intrusion detection systems (IDS) to monitor network traffic for suspicious activities. Continuous monitoring of network traffic helps in early detection and response to potential security incidents.

risks.name: Unauthorized Access
risks.description: If unauthorized individuals gain access to the network, they can steal or manipulate sensitive data, leading to data breaches and financial losses. Periodic access reviews help mitigate this risk.

risks.name: Employee Error
risks.description: Employees might inadvertently compromise network security through phishing attacks or other social engineering techniques. Regular security awareness training helps to reduce this risk.

risks.name: Undetected Intrusions
risks.description: Without proper monitoring, intrusions can go undetected, leading to prolonged exposure to security threats. Implementing IDS helps in early detection and response to such threats.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 27031:2011
standard.description: ISO/IEC 27031:2011 provides guidelines for information and communication technology (ICT) readiness for business continuity. It ensures an organization's IT infrastructure is prepared for any interruptions and can continue operations with minimal impact.

requirements.name: Establish DR Strategy
requirements.description: Develop a comprehensive disaster recovery strategy that covers all critical IT assets. This plan should include steps for disaster identification, response, and recovery.

requirements.name: Regular Testing
requirements.description: Implement regular testing protocols of the disaster recovery plan to ensure it is effective and up-to-date.

standard.name: NIST SP 800-34
standard.description: The NIST Special Publication 800-34 provides guidelines to federal agencies for developing and maintaining continuity of operations (COOP) plans. It focuses on ensuring that IT systems can recover swiftly from disruptions.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment
requirements.description: Conduct regular risk assessments to identify vulnerabilities and the potential impact on IT systems. Update recovery plans accordingly.

requirements.name: Resource Allocation
requirements.description: Ensure adequate resources are allocated for the implementation and maintenance of the disaster recovery plan.

controls.name: Backup Verification
controls.description: Conduct regular verification of backups to ensure data integrity and availability.

controls.name: Disaster Recovery Drills
controls.description: Perform periodic DR drills to simulate different disaster scenarios and validate the plan's effectiveness.

controls.name: Third-Party Audit
controls.description: Engage independent third-party auditors to assess the disaster recovery plan's comprehensiveness and effectiveness.

risks.name: Data Corruption
risks.description: If backups are not regularly verified, corrupted data may go unnoticed, leading to potential data loss during recovery.

risks.name: Plan Ineffectiveness
risks.description: Without periodic drills, the disaster recovery plan may fail to address real-world scenarios, resulting in prolonged downtime.

risks.name: Non-Compliance
risks.description: Failing to undergo third-party audits may result in non-compliance with regulatory standards, negatively impacting organizational reputation.

standard.name: ISO 55000
standard.description: ISO 55000 provides an overview of the principles and terminology of asset management. It applies to all types of assets and is relevant to all sizes of organizations, providing a common language for asset management key principles.

requirements.name: Asset Management Policy
requirements.description: Organizations must establish an asset management policy aligned with strategic objectives. The policy should define asset management principles and state the commitment of leadership to asset management practices.

requirements.name: Asset Information Strategy
requirements.description: Develop a strategy to collect, manage, and use asset information effectively. The strategy should ensure information accuracy, reliability, and availability to support asset-related decision making.

standard.name: NIST SP 800-53
standard.description: NIST Special Publication 800-53 provides a catalog of security and privacy controls for federal information systems and organizations. It supports risk management frameworks and ensures the safety and integrity of assets, especially in IT environments.

requirements.name: Asset Inventory
requirements.description: Organizations should develop and maintain an up-to-date inventory of all assets. The inventory must include details such as asset type, owner, value, and criticality to operations.

requirements.name: Access Control Policy
requirements.description: Implement policies to control physical and logical access to assets. The policy should define roles and responsibilities, enforce least privilege principles, and include mechanisms for regular review and adjustment.

controls.name: Regular Asset Audits
controls.description: Conduct regular audits of asset inventories to ensure all assets are accounted for and records are accurate. This includes physical verification and reconciliation with inventory records. Frequency: Semi-annual.

controls.name: Access Control Systems
controls.description: Deploy access control systems for physical and digital assets, including locks, badges, passwords, and biometric systems. These systems should be monitored and tested regularly. Frequency: Ongoing.

controls.name: Asset Lifecycle Management
controls.description: Implement an asset lifecycle management process, covering acquisition, utilization, maintenance, and disposal of assets. Regular reviews to assess asset performance and alignment with organizational objectives. Frequency: Quarterly.

risks.name: Theft or Loss of Assets
risks.description: Loss or theft of assets can result in financial loss, operational disruptions, and data breaches. Regular audits help mitigate this by ensuring all assets are accounted for.

risks.name: Unauthorized Access
risks.description: Unauthorized access to assets can lead to data breaches, data loss, and operational disruptions. Access control systems minimize this risk by limiting access to authorized personnel only.

risks.name: Asset Performance Decline
risks.description: If assets are not properly managed throughout their lifecycle, their performance may decline, leading to inefficiencies and increased operational costs. Asset lifecycle management ensures assets remain effective and aligned with organizational goals.

standard.name: ISO 22301:2019
standard.description: ISO 22301:2019 specifies requirements to implement, maintain, and improve a management system to protect against, reduce the likelihood of, and ensure your business recovers from disruptive incidents. The standard is applicable to all organizations, regardless of type, size, and nature.

requirements.name: Business Impact Analysis
requirements.description: Identify and evaluate the impact of disruptions to business operations. This includes assessing the effects on critical business functions and the required resources to maintain continuity.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment
requirements.description: Conduct a risk assessment to identify potential threats and vulnerabilities that can cause disruptions, and evaluate the likelihood and impact of these risks.

standard.name: NIST SP 800-34 Rev. 1
standard.description: NIST Special Publication 800-34 Rev. 1 provides a framework for determining impact levels, developing recovery strategies, and implementing incident management and recovery processes for information systems in both non-federal and federal organizations.

requirements.name: Incident Response Planning
requirements.description: Create and maintain an incident response plan outlining roles, responsibilities, and specific steps for addressing incidents.

requirements.name: Recovery Strategy Development
requirements.description: Develop and document strategies for recovering and restoring operations after an incident, prioritizing critical functions and resources.

controls.name: Regular Simulation Exercises
controls.description: Conduct regular (at least bi-annual) simulation exercises to test and evaluate the effectiveness of the incident management plans. This helps to identify gaps and areas for improvement in the processes.

controls.name: Continuous Monitoring and Review
controls.description: Implement continuous monitoring and periodic review (quarterly) of incident management processes and controls to ensure they remain effective and up-to-date.

controls.name: Incident Reporting and Documentation
controls.description: Maintain a detailed and up-to-date log of all incidents, including the nature of the incident, actions taken, and eventual outcomes. This continuous documentation helps in assessing trends and improving future responses.

risks.name: Lack of Preparedness
risks.description: Failure to conduct regular simulations may result in inadequate readiness during an actual incident, increasing recovery time and operational downtime.

risks.name: Ineffective Incident Management
risks.description: Without continuous monitoring and review, incident management controls may become outdated, leading to ineffective responses to new types of incidents.

risks.name: Inadequate Documentation
risks.description: Failure to properly log and document incidents may hinder post-incident analysis and the ability to implement necessary improvements, causing repeated failures.

standard.name: ISO 27001
standard.description: ISO 27001 is an international standard for information security management systems (ISMS). It provides a systematic approach to managing sensitive company information, ensuring it remains secure. It includes people, processes, and IT systems by applying a risk management process.

requirements.name: Information Security Policy
requirements.description: Establish, implement, maintain, and continually improve an information security management system in accordance with the requirements of ISO 27001. Create policies and procedures to ensure third-party technology providers comply with the organization’s information security standards.

requirements.name: Supplier Risk Management
requirements.description: Assess and manage the risks related to suppliers' access to the organization's information. This includes the evaluation of suppliers' information security controls and the establishment of security requirements in supplier agreements.

standard.name: NIST SP 800-161
standard.description: NIST SP 800-161 provides guidance to organizations on identifying, assessing, and managing cybersecurity risks throughout the supply chain. It's particularly relevant for federal agencies and critical infrastructure sectors.

requirements.name: Supply Chain Risk Management Policy
requirements.description: Develop, document, and disseminate a supply chain risk management policy that addresses purpose, scope, roles, responsibilities, and management commitment.

requirements.name: Supply Chain Risk Assessments
requirements.description: Conduct regular supply chain risk assessments to identify and mitigate risks posed by third-party technology suppliers. Ensure continued oversight and monitoring.

controls.name: Third-Party Compliance Audits
controls.description: Conduct regular (at least annual) audits of third-party technology providers to ensure compliance with organizational security policies and standards. This includes reviewing vendor compliance reports, on-site assessments, and penetration testing.

controls.name: Supplier Security Agreements
controls.description: Establish and enforce security requirements in agreements with technology suppliers. Ensure that contracts include clauses requiring suppliers to implement specified security controls and undergo periodic security audits.

risks.name: Data Breach
risks.description: Unauthorized access to sensitive information through third-party systems could result in data breaches. This risk is heightened if third-party providers do not adhere to established security protocols.

risks.name: Supplier Non-Compliance
risks.description: Failure of third-party suppliers to comply with security requirements could pose significant risks, including data breaches, regulatory penalties, and loss of customer trust.

standard.name: ISO 22301:2019
standard.description: ISO 22301:2019 specifies requirements to implement, maintain, and improve a management system to protect against, reduce the likelihood of, and ensure your business recovers from disruptive incidents. It is applicable to all businesses regardless of type, size, or nature.

requirements.name: Business Impact Analysis (BIA)
requirements.description: Conduct a Business Impact Analysis (BIA) to identify the effects of disruption to critical business functions and processes. It helps prioritize actions for restoring operations and is critical for effective BCM.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment
requirements.description: Perform a comprehensive risk assessment to identify threats, vulnerabilities, and impacts on business operations. This aids in developing mitigation strategies.

standard.name: NIST SP 800-34
standard.description: NIST Special Publication 800-34 provides a guide for creating a comprehensive Business Continuity Plan (BCP) and Disaster Recovery Plan (DRP). It is particularly applicable to federal information systems but can be adapted for any organization.

requirements.name: Contingency Planning
requirements.description: Develop a contingency plan that outlines how the organization will respond to various types of disruptions. Include recovery strategies and resources needed.

requirements.name: Testing and Exercises
requirements.description: Regularly test and exercise the BCM and DR plans to ensure they are effective and that staff are trained to respond to actual disruptions.

controls.name: Quarterly BIA Review
controls.description: Conduct quarterly reviews of the Business Impact Analysis to ensure the data remains current and reflective of business priorities.

controls.name: Annual Risk Assessment
controls.description: Perform an annual risk assessment to update the understanding of risks, impacts, and mitigation strategies.

controls.name: Semi-Annual Contingency Plan Testing
controls.description: Execute semi-annual tests of the contingency plan to validate its effectiveness and update it based on lessons learned.

risks.name: Outdated Impact Data
risks.description: If the Business Impact Analysis is not regularly updated, the organization might rely on outdated data, leading to poor prioritization during a disruption.

risks.name: Unidentified Risks
risks.description: Failing to perform regular risk assessments can result in unidentified risks that could cause significant disruptions.

risks.name: Ineffective Response
risks.description: Without regular testing, the contingency plan might be ineffective. This could result in uncoordinated responses and longer recovery times.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 27001
standard.description: This standard provides a framework for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an information security management system (ISMS). It is designed to ensure the selection of adequate and proportionate security controls that protect information assets and give confidence to interested parties.

requirements.name: Information Security Policy
requirements.description: Develop and maintain an information security policy that outlines the approach to managing information security, including objectives, scope, and responsibilities.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment and Treatment
requirements.description: Conduct regular risk assessments to identify, analyze, and evaluate risks. Implement appropriate risk treatment plans to mitigate identified risks.

standard.name: NIST Cybersecurity Framework
standard.description: This framework provides a policy framework of computer security guidance for how private sector organizations can assess and improve their ability to prevent, detect, and respond to cyber attacks. It is designed to complement existing business and cybersecurity operations.

requirements.name: Identify
requirements.description: Develop an organizational understanding to manage cybersecurity risk to systems, people, assets, data, and capabilities.

requirements.name: Detect
requirements.description: Develop and implement appropriate activities to identify the occurrence of a cybersecurity event.

controls.name: Regular Security Audits
controls.description: Conduct regular security audits to ensure compliance with established information security policies and procedures. Frequency: Quarterly

controls.name: Continuous Monitoring
controls.description: Implement continuous monitoring systems to detect and respond to information security threats in real-time. Frequency: Ongoing

controls.name: Employee Training Programs
controls.description: Conduct regular employee training programs on cybersecurity awareness and best practices. Frequency: Bi-annually

risks.name: Data Breach
risks.description: A data breach can result in the unauthorized access and disclosure of sensitive information, leading to financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences. If regular security audits are not conducted, vulnerabilities may go undetected and be exploited.

risks.name: Advanced Persistent Threats (APTs)
risks.description: APTs involve prolonged and targeted cyberattacks aimed at stealing information or disrupting operations. Continuous monitoring helps detect and respond to these threats in real-time, minimizing damage.

risks.name: Phishing Attacks
risks.description: Phishing attacks aim to deceive employees into providing sensitive information, leading to potential data breaches and financial loss. Employee training programs help in recognizing and preventing such attacks.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 27001
standard.description: ISO/IEC 27001 is an international standard for managing information security. It provides a systematic approach to managing sensitive company information so that it remains secure. It includes people, processes, and IT systems by applying a risk management process.

requirements.name: Information Security Policy
requirements.description: An information security policy is a set of rules or guidelines that an organization establishes to ensure that its IT infrastructure and information assets are secure from unauthorized access or damage. It lays the groundwork for implementing and managing security controls.

requirements.name: Risk Assessment
requirements.description: Conduct regular risk assessments to identify and mitigate potential threats to the organization's information security. This is important for preemptively identifying vulnerabilities in the software distribution process.

standard.name: NIST SP 800-53
standard.description: NIST SP 800-53 provides a catalog of security and privacy controls for federal information systems and organizations. The purpose of these controls is to protect organizational operations, assets, and individuals from a diverse set of threats including hostile attacks, natural disasters, and errors.

requirements.name: Access Control Policy and Procedures
requirements.description: Develop documented access control policy and procedures to manage who has access to what information and prevent unauthorized access to software distribution networks.

requirements.name: Audit and Accountability
requirements.description: Implement mechanisms for auditing and accountability to ensure that activities related to software distribution are tracked and monitored for compliance.

controls.name: Software Validation and Verification
controls.description: Perform validation and verification of all software before distribution to ensure that it meets functional and security requirements. This is crucial to prevent the distribution of flawed or insecure software that could be exploited.

controls.name: Access Controls
controls.description: Implement strict access controls for software distribution channels to ensure only authorized personnel can access sensitive areas. Regularly review and update access permissions.

controls.name: Regular Security Audits
controls.description: Conduct regular security audits to identify and rectify potential vulnerabilities within the software distribution system. This ensures continuous compliance with established standards and mitigates risks before they become issues.

risks.name: Unauthorized Software Modification
risks.description: Unauthorized modifications to software during the distribution phase can compromise the integrity and security of the software. This can lead to security breaches and operational failures.

risks.name: Access Breach
risks.description: Unauthorized access to the software distribution system can result in data leaks, modification of distribution files, and a breach of confidential information. Such incidents can damage the company's reputation and lead to financial losses.

risks.name: Non-Compliance
risks.description: Non-compliance with industry standards and regulatory requirements can result in legal penalties, loss of certifications, and increased vulnerability to attacks. Regular audits help in maintaining compliance.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 27001
standard.description: An international standard for managing information security. This standard provides a framework for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continually improving an information security management system (ISMS). It is applicable to any organization, regardless of size, type, or nature.

requirements.name: Access Control Policy
requirements.description: Establish, document, and review access control policies and procedures to ensure that only authorized users have access to the required information and resources. This is crucial for maintaining data integrity and security.

requirements.name: Operational Procedures
requirements.description: Document and maintain operational procedures to ensure the consistency and repeatability of activities, thus reducing the risk of errors and improving efficiency and compliance.

standard.name: ITIL Service Operation
standard.description: ITIL Service Operation standard provides guidance on achieving the delivery of agreed levels of service for both end-users and customers. It focuses on the efficiency of IT services and the technology supporting them. This standard is applicable to IT service management.

requirements.name: Incident Management
requirements.description: Develop and implement processes for managing incidents to minimize their adverse impact on business operations and ensure their quick resolution. Effective incident management helps in maintaining service quality and reliability.

requirements.name: Service Request Management
requirements.description: Establish and manage a process for handling service requests from users, ensuring they are addressed promptly and effectively. This improves user satisfaction and ensures smooth operations.

controls.name: Automated Job Scheduling
controls.description: Utilize automated job scheduling tools to ensure that jobs are completed accurately and on time. Automation reduces the chances of human error, enhances efficiency, and ensures adherence to scheduled timelines. This control should be monitored on a daily basis.

controls.name: Access Controls Implementation
controls.description: Implement robust access control mechanisms to ensure that only authorized personnel can schedule, modify, or cancel jobs. This control is vital for maintaining the integrity and security of the job scheduling process. The effectiveness of this control should be reviewed quarterly.

controls.name: Regular Review and Audit of Job Logs
controls.description: Conduct regular reviews and audits of job logs to ensure that all jobs are executed as planned and any deviations are investigated. This control helps in detecting potential issues early and maintaining the reliability of operations. Audits should be conducted on a weekly basis.

risks.name: Job Execution Failure

controls.name: Incident Response Plan
controls.description: Develop and maintain a comprehensive incident response plan that details the procedures for responding to cyber threats. This plan should be tested and reviewed quarterly.

controls.name: Security Awareness Training
controls.description: Conduct regular security awareness training for all employees to educate them about the latest cyber threats and best practices for safeguarding information. This training should occur bi-annually.

risks.name: Data Breach
risks.description: A data breach could result in the loss of sensitive information, leading to financial loss, reputational damage, and legal consequences. This risk is associated with inadequate information security policies and access controls.

risks.name: Delayed Incident Response
risks.description: Delayed response to cyber incidents can exacerbate the impact, resulting in prolonged operational disruptions and increased recovery costs. This risk is mitigated by having a robust incident response plan.

risks.name: Insufficient Threat Intelligence
risks.description: Without adequate threat intelligence sharing, the organization may miss critical information about potential threats, making them more vulnerable to attacks. This risk is mitigated by protocols for threat intelligence sharing.

standard.name: ISO/IEC 27001

This standard is applicable to all organizations, regardless of size or industry, and includes requirements for establishing, implementing, maintaining, and continuously improving an ISMS.

requirements.name: Event Logging
requirements.description: Ensure that all significant events are logged and can be reviewed. This includes successful and failed login attempts, changes to system configurations, and other security-relevant events. This logging helps in identifying potential security incidents and maintaining accountability.

requirements.name: Log Retention
requirements.description: Logs must be retained for a sufficient period to support incident investigation and analysis. The retention period must comply with regulatory requirements and internal policies to ensure traceability and accountability.

standard.name: NIST Special Publication 800-92
standard.description: NIST SP 800-92 provides guidelines on computer security log management. It offers a framework for establishing a log management infrastructure and ensuring effective log collection, storage, and analysis. It is applicable to federal agencies and other entities managing sensitive information systems.

requirements.name: Log Management Infrastructure
requirements.description: Develop and implement a comprehensive log management infrastructure that ensures secure log collection, transmission, storage, and disposal. This is essential for maintaining log integrity and supporting forensic investigations.

requirements.name: Regular Log Review and Analysis
requirements.description: Perform regular review and analysis of logs to identify and respond to security incidents promptly. This helps in early detection of malicious activities and mitigating potential threats before they cause significant damage.

controls.name: Centralized Log Management System
controls.description: Implement a centralized log management system to collect, store, and analyze logs from all relevant systems and devices. This control ensures that logs are centrally managed, making it easier to review and respond to security incidents. The system should be monitored on a daily basis to identify any anomalies or signs of potential security breaches.

controls.name: Automated Log Analysis Tools
controls.description: Deploy automated tools for analyzing logs to detect unusual patterns or behaviors that may indicate security incidents. Automated analysis helps in quickly identifying potential threats and reduces the reliance on manual review processes. These tools should be configured to run continuously or at regular intervals, such as hourly or daily, depending on the criticality of the monitored systems.

controls.name: Access Controls for Log Data
controls.description: Establish strict access controls for log data to ensure that only authorized personnel can view or modify logs. This control is crucial for maintaining the integrity and confidentiality of log data, preventing unauthorized access or tampering. Access controls should be reviewed and updated regularly to reflect changes in personnel or organizational roles.

risks.name: Undetected Security Incidents
risks.description: If security incidents are not promptly detected, they may lead to unauthorized access, data breaches, or other malicious activities that can significantly harm the organization. Effective log management and review are vital in identifying and responding to such incidents.

risks.name: Log Data Tampering
risks.description: Unauthorized access to log data may result in tampering, making it difficult to trace and investigate security incidents. This can impede response efforts and allow malicious activities to continue undetected. Implementing access controls helps mitigate this risk.

risks.name: Delayed Incident Response
risks.description: Delayed response to security incidents can result in extended periods of exposure to threats, increasing the potential impact on the organization. Regular and automated log analysis is essential for timely detection and mitigation of security risks.

requirements.name: Security Controls

standard.name: NIST SP 800-53

requirements.name: Continuous Monitoring
requirements.description: Establish a continuous monitoring strategy and program to ensure security controls are effective and to detect and respond to security incidents in a timely manner.

requirements.name: Access Control
requirements.description: Enforce strict access control measures to ensure that only authorized individuals have access to information and systems. This includes role-based access, multi-factor authentication, and regular access reviews.

controls.name: Regular Risk Assessments

controls.name: Security Control Implementation

controls.name: Continuous Monitoring Program
controls.description: Establish and maintain a continuous monitoring program to oversee the effectiveness of security controls. Regular system checks and audits should be performed monthly to ensure compliance with security standards.

risks.name: Poor Risk Identification
risks.description: Failure to accurately identify risks can lead to unmitigated vulnerabilities, resulting in potential breaches of sensitive information and loss of stakeholder trust. risks.name: Ineffective Security Measures
risks.description: If security measures are not effectively implemented or updated, the organization may be susceptible to cyber attacks. Ensuring the consistent implementation and updating of security controls is vital to protect against breaches.

risks.name: Undetected Security Incidents
risks.description: Without continuous monitoring, security incidents may go undetected, leading to data breaches and operational disruptions. A continuous monitoring program helps in the early detection and response to such incidents, minimizing their impact.

requirements.name: Access Control

requirements.name: Audit and Accountability Policy and Procedures

controls.name: Regular Security Audits

controls.name: Access Reviews

requirements.name: Least Privilege
requirements.description: Implement the principle of least privilege, ensuring that users have the minimum level of access necessary to perform their job functions. This minimizes potential damages from accidents or malicious actions.

requirements.name: Access Control Monitoring
requirements.description: Continuously monitor and review access control measures to ensure they are functioning correctly and adapt them as necessary to respond to evolving security threats.

controls.name: Role-Based Access Control (RBAC)
controls.description: Implement role-based access control to ensure that access rights are assigned based on the role of the user within the organization. Monitor and review roles and access regularly.

controls.name: Multi-Factor Authentication (MFA)
controls.description: Require multi-factor authentication for all access to sensitive systems. Regularly review and update the authentication methods to protect against emerging threats.

controls.name: Access Review Audits

risks.name: Unauthorized Access

risks.name: Credential Theft
risks.description: Risk of credentials being stolen through phishing or other attacks, allowing attackers to access sensitive systems.

risks.name: Access Control Misconfigurations

requirements.name: Awareness Training

requirements.name: Regular Updates

standard.name: NIST SP 800-50

requirements.name: Program Development

requirements.name: Evaluation and Improvement
requirements.description: Regularly evaluate the effectiveness of the information security training program and make necessary improvements. This ensures the program stays relevant and effective in mitigating security risks.

controls.name: Mandatory Training Sessions
controls.description: Institute mandatory training sessions for all employees upon hiring and annually thereafter. This ensures that all employees are consistently informed about the company's information security policies and procedures.

controls.name: Phishing Simulation Exercises
controls.description: Conduct regular phishing simulation exercises to educate employees on recognizing and handling phishing attempts. This helps to reinforce training and assess employees' ability to respond to security threats.

controls.name: Policy Review Meetings
controls.description: Hold quarterly policy review meetings to update and reinforce information security policies and procedures. This ensures that employees are kept up-to-date with the latest security practices and changes.

risks.name: Human Error
risks.description: Employees may inadvertently cause security breaches due to a lack of awareness or understanding of security policies. risks.name: Phishing Attacks
risks.description: Employees may fall victim to phishing attacks, leading to unauthorized access to sensitive information. This can result in data breaches, financial losses, and damage to the organization's credibility. The Phishing Simulation Exercises control addresses this risk by training employees to identify and respond to phishing attempts.

risks.name: Policy Non-Compliance
risks.description: Employees may not comply with information security policies if they are not regularly updated and reinforced. This can lead to vulnerabilities and security breaches. standard.name: PMI PMBOK
standard.description: The Project Management Institute's Project Management Body of Knowledge (PMBOK) is a set of standard terminology and guidelines for project management. It aims to provide project managers with the fundamental practices needed for delivering projects successfully.

requirements.name: Integration Management
requirements.description: Ensures that project components are properly coordinated. This includes developing project charters, project management plans, and managing project knowledge.

requirements.name: Risk Management
requirements.description: Involves identifying, analyzing, and responding to project risks. It includes risk planning, risk identification, qualitative and quantitative risk analysis, and risk response planning.

requirements.name: Quality Management
requirements.description: Focuses on ensuring that the project outputs meet the required standards and stakeholder expectations. It involves quality planning, quality assurance, and quality control.

requirements.name: Stakeholder Management

requirements.name: Resource Management
requirements.description: Involves planning, estimating, and acquiring resources. It includes developing resource plans, estimating resource needs, and managing project teams.

controls.name: Monthly Project Review Meetings
controls.description: Conduct monthly project review meetings to assess the progress of the project, identify any issues or risks, and plan necessary corrective actions.

controls.name: Risk Register Maintenance

controls.name: Quality Audits
controls.description: Conduct quality audits at key project milestones to ensure that project deliverables meet the required quality standards.

risks.name: Quality Failures

requirements.name: Align, Plan and Organize

requirements.name: Build, Acquire and Implement

controls.name: Regular IT Governance Reviews

controls.name: Strategic Risk Assessments

risks.name: Misalignment of IT and Business Strategy

risks.name: Inadequate Risk Management
risks.description: Failure to identify and address risks related to strategic IT initiatives can result in project failures, financial losses, and damage to organizational reputation.

standard.name: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR)
standard.description: The GDPR is a regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy in the European Union and the European Economic Area. The primary aim of the GDPR is to give control to individuals over their personal data and to simplify the regulatory environment for international business by unifying the regulation within the EU.

requirements.name: Data Subject Rights
requirements.description: Organizations must respect and facilitate the rights of data subjects, including the right to access, rectify, and erase their data. This is essential for maintaining compliance with GDPR and ensuring transparency and trust with data subjects.

requirements.name: Data Breach Notification
requirements.description: In the event of a personal data breach, organizations must notify the appropriate supervisory authority within 72 hours and communicate the breach to affected data subjects without undue delay. Timely notification helps mitigate potential harm and regulatory penalties.

requirements.name: Information Security Policy

requirements.name: Risk Assessment and Treatment

controls.name: Encryption of Data at Rest and in Transit
controls.description: Ensure that all sensitive data is encrypted both at rest and in transit to protect against unauthorized access and breaches. Regularly review and update encryption protocols to maintain security standards.

controls.name: Access Controls and User Authentication
controls.description: Implement strong access controls and multi-factor authentication to ensure that only authorized users have access to sensitive data. Regular audits should be conducted to review user access and authentication processes.

controls.name: Data Protection Impact Assessments (DPIAs)
controls.description: Conduct DPIAs for processing activities that are likely to result in a high risk to the rights and freedoms of data subjects. Ensure that results of DPIAs are documented and risks are mitigated appropriately.

risks.name: Data Breach

risks.name: Unauthorized Access

risks.name: Non-Compliance with GDPR

requirements.name: Detect

risks.name: Ineffective Response to Incidents

requirements.name: Access Control
requirements.description: Control access to information and IT systems based on business and security requirements. This includes identifying, authenticating, and authorizing users.

risks.name: Backup Integrity Failure

requirements.name: Strategy Alignment

risks.name: Inadequate Risk Management
